moves.1. e4 e5: Decided to play Kings Pawn as opposed to the Sicilian, which is what I more commonly play.
moves.4. a3: He leaves the opening book. I assume to limit the mobility of the Queen's Knight as it is the only major piece I have as yet developed.
moves.4... Nf6: Nf6 Applies pressure to the pawn at e4.
moves.5. d3: Removes the threat on pawn at e4.
moves.5... d5: I decided to aggressively contend for the center. I was expecting 6. exd5, Nxd5, 7. Bxd5, Qxd5.
moves.6. exd5 Nxd5 7. h3: Instead of Bxd5, white plays h3. I was not sure the rational for this move, perhaps just to prevent Bg4, pinning the knight in place?
moves.7... Be6: I instead slide the bishop behind the knight. Having the bishops at e6 and d6 is a comfortable position for me.
moves.8. Ba2: White's retreat to a2 allows me to comfortably develop in the center.
moves.8... Bd6: It also has opened up the kingside castle, should I choose to.
moves.9. c4: c4 - threatens the knight at d5. My options are: Nb6, Nf4, Nf6. I did not want to return the knight to f6 and allow white to pressure on the queenside. I avoided b6 because I really wanted to attack white's kingside and b6 would put the knight out of position. Therefore I decided on Nf4.
moves.10... exf4: White has forced the exchange. Material is even. At this position, I feel that the neither of us has an clear advantage. (which I am fine with when playing black, 10 moves in)
moves.11... a6: a6 is designed to limit the Knight's mobility. I probably should have moved Bc5
moves.12. O-O O-O: Matching Castles. I was actually hoping he would castle. I wanted to attack behind the castle and use the positioning of the bishops to my advantage.
moves.13. Qc2: I'm not sure what white's plan is here. Perhaps he was thinking along the same lines and was looking to apply pressure to the castled king.
moves.13... Qd7: The knight on f3 was a little annoying so I moved the queen up to attempt bypass its zone of control.
moves.14. Kh2: Kh2?! Intersting move. This was not what I expected, but it did stop me from Bxh3 15. gxh3, Qxh3 which I was considering.
moves.14... Rad8: Rad8?? I have no idea what my rational for this move was, probably just wanted to get it off the edge of the board. I think I should have gone Ne5 to try and force a swap with the pesky knight on f3. The good news is this rook is a lifesaver later in the match.
moves.15... Bf5: Again, I probably should have played Ne5.
moves.16. Qc1: White removes the pin on d3.
moves.17. Nxe5 Bxe5: White decided to swap. I now have a discovered check if I move the pawn. Material is again even.
moves.18. f3: White sees the potential and blocks the f4 pawn.
moves.18... Qe6: Qe6 was to allow me to pressure whites d3 pawn.
moves.19. Nd5: White impedes my rooks movement and removes the threat on d3.
moves.19... c6: My expectations: c6 should force Nb4, which I could pressure with a5 and force Nc2 and allows me to capture the pawn at d3.
moves.20. Nxf4: Nxf4?! Blunder. White takes the pawn but hangs the Knight.
moves.21. g3 gxf4 22. gxf4 Bc7: I could have moved Bg7 which protects the king from the empty file. However, I wanted to keep the pressure on the diagonal.
moves.23. Rfg1+: expected: forces the king into the corner.
moves.24... Qd6: Moves queen to safety and applies pressure to f4.
moves.25. Re5: Threatens the bishop a f5. removes the pressure on f4.
moves.25... Qxd3: Qxd3?! Mistake. I thought this move to be exceedingly clever when I made it. It threatened the rook, protected my bishop and won me a pawn. I did not realize it also put my queen on the same diagonal as the king...
moves.26. Rxf5 Qxf5: At +4 in this position, I was thinking this was a won game.
moves.27. Bb1:
White springs the trap. At this point I realized that 25. Qf6 was the correct move to protect the bishop and threaten the rook.

I have only one option here, the rook on d8 turns out to be very helpful.
moves.27... Rd3 28. Qf1: Qf1. White steps into the forced mate. Qf1 leads to 28...Qxf4+, Rg3 Qxg3+, Kh1 Qh2# and checkmate. White really should have taken the rook. It would have allowed white to get back into the game.
